question: How should an institution treat the recognition of hedges when it uses an internal hedge booked in the trading book to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure, and how does this interact with the requirement to recognise hedges against interest rate risks (including internal hedges meeting Article 106(3))?
gold_answer: An institution may recognise the effect of hedges against interest rate risks, and that recognition can include internal hedges provided they meet the requirements laid down in Article 106(3). [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d] However, where the institution uses an internal hedge in the form of a credit derivative booked in its trading book to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure, the non-trading book exposure must not be treated as hedged for risk-weighted exposure amount calculations unless the institution also buys a corresponding credit derivative from an eligible third party protection provider that meets the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] If that third-party protection is purchased and is recognised as a hedge of the non-trading book exposure for capital requirement calculations, the institution must then ensure that neither the internal credit derivative hedge nor the external credit derivative hedge is included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] In practice, this means that even though internal hedges can be recognised in the interest rate risk context when they satisfy Article 106(3), the specific derogation for internal credit-derivative hedges requires additional third-party protection and imposes a trading-book exclusion for both legs once the hedge is recognised for capital purposes. [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d][#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11]
source_text: (iv) the recognition of the effect of hedges against those interest rate risks, including internal hedges that meet the requirements laid down in Article 106(3) ;
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraphs 1 and 2 , when an institution hedges a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure using a credit derivative booked in its trading book using an internal hedge, institutions shall ensure that the non-trading book exposure or counterparty risk exposure shall not be deemed to be hedged for the purposes of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless the institution purchases from an eligible third party protection provider a corresponding credit derivative meeting the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. Without prejudice to point (h) of Article 299(2), where such third party protection is purchased and recognised as a hedge of a non-trading book exposure for the purposes of calculating capital requirements, institutions shall ensure that neither the internal nor external credit derivative hedge shall be included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements.

question: When a firm determines the linear formula component that represents long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations relating to general insurance business, how must it calculate that component consistently with the required approach for the relevant linear MCR measures, and what restriction applies to the technical provisions or premiums written used in that calculation?
gold_answer: MCR(l,gi) is the linear formula component that denotes the firm’s long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations relating to general insurance business [#SRC:bcc921ae0bcf10dd]. When calculating this component, the firm must apply the same calculation approach as is used for the corresponding linear MCR measures, because MCR(gi,gi) and MCR(l,gi) are required to be calculated in the same way as MCR(linear,gi) and MCR(linear,l) respectively [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478]. In applying that consistent method, the firm must also ensure that the inputs used are appropriately scoped: the technical provisions or premiums written included in the calculation must only relate to the firm’s general insurance and reinsurance obligations [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478]. Read together, this means the firm should treat MCR(l,gi) as the specific linear component for long-term obligations tied to general insurance business, while still following the mandated linear calculation methodology and limiting the underlying data to general insurance and reinsurance obligations, rather than including amounts that relate to other types of business [#SRC:bcc921ae0bcf10dd] [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478].
source_text: (2) MCR(l,gi) denotes the linear formula component for long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations relating to general insurance business calculated in accordance with 4A.5 .
target_text: MCR (gi,gi) and MCR (l,gi) must be calculated in the same way as MCR (linear,gi) and MCR (linear,l) referred to in Minimum Capital Requirement 3B and 3C respectively, but the technical provisions or premiums written used in the calculation must only relate to the firm’s general insurance and reinsurance obligations .

question: Can an institution work out one exposure value for a whole netting set under a contractual netting agreement, and at the same time permanently mix the relevant methods? Does it matter if it is a single institution or within a group?
gold_answer: An institution is allowed to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level for all transactions covered by a contractual netting agreement, but only if it meets the conditions attached to that permission [#TGT:1600c3275d4f97ef]. Separately, the rules on permanently combining the relevant methods draw a line between group use and single-institution use: institutions may combine those methods on a permanent basis within a group, but a single institution must not combine them on a permanent basis [#SRC:05cc39f7a09a2d78]. Putting these together, the netting-set exposure value permission does not remove the prohibition on permanent method-combination for a single institution. So, an institution may be able to compute one exposure value for the netting set if the contractual netting agreement conditions are met [#TGT:1600c3275d4f97ef], but if it is acting as a single institution it still cannot permanently mix the relevant methods; that permanent mixing is only allowed when done within a group [#SRC:05cc39f7a09a2d78].
source_text: Institutions may use in combination the methods set out in Sections 3 to 6 on a permanent basis within a group. A single institution shall not use in combination the methods set out in Sections 3 to 6 on a permanent basis.

question: If a firm’s participation in a financial and credit institution is big enough that it must be taken off basic own funds in full (because it is over 10% of the listed 3A.1(1) items), what should the firm do if it cannot apply Own Funds 3K.5 in a simple way to work out where the deduction goes?
gold_answer: When calculating basic own funds, the firm must subtract the full value of a participation in a financial and credit institution if that participation exceeds 10% of the items included in 3A.1(1)(a), 3A.1(1)(b), 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f). [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18] To carry out the calculations required by Own Funds 3K that underpin this reduction, the firm should use Guidelines 4 and 5 as calculation support. [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e] If the subtraction is a deduction from own-funds and the firm cannot apply Own Funds 3K.5 in a straightforward manner, it should use Guideline 6 to decide which tier of own-funds the adjustment should be applied to. [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e] In practice, the firm (i) checks whether the participation exceeds the 10% threshold against the specified 3A.1(1) items, (ii) reduces basic own funds by the full value once the threshold is exceeded, and (iii) uses Guideline 6 to allocate the deduction to the correct own-funds tier when Own Funds 3K.5 cannot be applied simply. [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18] [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]
source_text: Firms should observe Guidelines 4 and 5 which support the carrying out of the calculations required by Own Funds 3K . Where a deduction from own-funds is necessary, and where a straightforward application of Own Funds 3K.5 is not possible, firms should follow Guideline 6 to identify the tier of own-funds to which the adjustment should apply.
target_text: A firm must, for the purpose of determining its basic own funds , reduce its basic own funds by the full value of participations , as referred to in 3K.6 , in a financial and credit institution that exceeds 10% of items included in 3A.1(1)(a) , 3A.1(1)(b) , 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f) .

question: When a firm does not meet its combined buffer and is therefore subject to a maximum distributable amount, how must the firm determine the applicable percentage factor for the product-based calculation, and how does the firm’s quartile position in its combined buffer constrain the portion of the relevant profits that can be distributed?
gold_answer: Where a firm does not meet its combined buffer, it faces restrictions on distributions and becomes subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA), which it must calculate as a product of a specified percentage and a profits measure [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The percentage factor is not discretionary: it must be selected from 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in, and that quartile-based mapping also defines the maximum portion of the relevant profits that can be distributed [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. Specifically, the quartiles are defined by how much of the combined buffer the firm meets: if the firm is in the first quartile (meeting between 75% and 100% of the combined buffer), it may distribute 60% of such profits; in the second quartile it may distribute 40%; in the third quartile 20%; and in the fourth quartile 0% [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d]. The profits input to the product is the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits, net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from the items referenced in the calculation requirement [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b].
source_text: Firms may use their combined buffer as required in times of stress, but should not use it in the normal course of business or propose to enter it as part of their base business plan. As set out in the PRA’s capital buffers rules, firms that do not meet their combined buffer shall face restrictions on their distributions, and be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA). The MDA must be calculated as the product of 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% (depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in) 3 and the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in Capital Buffers 4.3(5)), net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from:
target_text: 3. Where firms are in the first quartile of their combined buffer (when they meet between 75% and 100% of it), 60% of such profits can be distributed. In the second quartile, 40% can be distributed; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%.

question: When preparing its solvent exit analysis, what must a firm do to identify, calibrate, and monitor solvent-exit indicators, and to what extent may it rely on and adapt its existing management information framework (including any indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations) rather than creating a new indicator set?
gold_answer: A firm should establish a set of indicators that it identifies and monitors to inform when it may need to initiate a solvent exit and whether a solvent exit is likely to be successful, and it should document those indicators in its solvent exit analysis [#TGT:7de9704d002276d9]. In doing so, the firm should calibrate the indicators on a forward-looking basis so they provide sufficient warning to enable the firm to produce a solvent exit execution plan and execute a solvent exit while it still has the necessary financial and non-financial resources [#TGT:7de9704d002276d9]. The indicators should cover both financial and non-financial metrics and may be expressed in quantitative and/or qualitative terms [#TGT:7de9704d002276d9]. To meet the relevant expectations, the firm is permitted to draw on and adapt its existing management information framework and any indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, without necessarily creating and monitoring a wholly new set of indicators [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32]. This means the firm can leverage existing reporting and monitoring structures, provided they support the solvent-exit-focused identification, monitoring, documentation, and forward-looking calibration described above [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] [#TGT:7de9704d002276d9].
source_text: To meet the expectations in paragraphs 2.7 and 2.8 , a firm may draw on and adapt its existing management information framework, and indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, 24 without necessarily creating and monitoring a new set of indicators.
target_text: A firm should identify and monitor indicators that would inform it about when it may need to initiate a solvent exit and whether the execution of a solvent exit is likely to be successful. A firm should set out these indicators in its solvent exit analysis. The calibration of indicators should be forward-looking and set such that they can provide sufficient warning to the firm to produce a solvent exit execution plan and to execute a solvent exit 22 while the firm still has the necessary financial and non-financial resources. These indicators should include financial and non-financial metrics in quantitative and/or qualitative terms.

question: When an Institution changes how it calculates the exposure value of derivative positions by moving between a single exposure value for transactions within a contractual netting agreement and separate exposure values per transaction, what notification to competent authorities is required, and what calculation approach applies depending on whether the Article 274(1) conditions are met?
gold_answer: An Institution that starts using, stops using, or switches between calculation methods for the exposure value of its derivative positions must notify the competent authorities of the relevant method it uses or ceases to use, as applicable, where that method is one of those set out in Section 4 or 5. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] In applying the calculation itself, the Institution may compute a single exposure value covering all transactions within a contractual netting agreement only when all conditions in Article 274(1) are satisfied; if those conditions are not met, it must instead compute an exposure value separately for each transaction. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Where separate calculation is required, each transaction is treated as its own netting set, which means the exposure value is determined on a transaction-by-transaction basis rather than aggregated under the contractual netting agreement. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Accordingly, the compliance action is twofold: (i) determine whether the Article 274(1) conditions permit a single exposure value across the contractual netting agreement or require separate exposure values per transaction, and (ii) notify the competent authorities of the Section 4 or 5 method being used or discontinued in connection with that exposure-value calculation for derivative positions. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]
source_text: Institutions shall notify the competent authorities of the methods set out in Section 4 or 5 that they use, or cease to use, as applicable, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: What do firms need to do to make sure they have enough realistic ways to rebuild capital and liquidity after a stress, including thinking about what peer firms might do, and how does scenario testing help prove the recovery plan and its options will work across different stresses?
gold_answer: Firms are expected to ensure they have sufficient credible options to restore their capital and liquidity positions to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress, and when judging how much capacity those options really have, they should consider the likely actions of peers in a stress (for example, whether issuing equity would be harder in a market-wide stress) [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d]. Scenario testing supports this by demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use across a range of different types of stress, rather than only under a single assumed set of conditions [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450]. It also allows firms to test how different parts of the plan would work together in those stresses, including how the options interact with indicators and governance, so the firm can show that the options it relies on remain credible and usable when the plan is executed under stress conditions that may be affected by peer behavior and broader market dynamics [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure they have sufficient credible options to restore their capital and liquidity positions to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress. In assessing the capacity of these options, firms should take into account the likely actions of peers in a stress. For example, firms should assess whether their ability to issue equity will be diminished in a market wide stress. See also ‘ (iv) Scenario testing ’ below.
target_text: Scenario testing is important for demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress, and testing how different elements of the plan (such as indicators, governance and options) would interact in these stresses.

question: When the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to a ‘UK trading bank’, how must the firm evidence senior management accountability for oversight of booking arrangements, and what approval consideration arises for parent or group-entity individuals who materially influence the firm’s UK regulated activities?
gold_answer: Where the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to a firm that falls within the described scope—namely, a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is headquartered in the UK or part of a UK-based group and that conducts investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas (referred to as ‘UK trading banks’)—the firm should treat those expectations as applicable in line with the stated delineation between expectations that apply to international banks alone and those that apply to international banks and UK trading banks [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]. In that context, the PRA expects the firm to allocate responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to record this appropriately in the firm’s Statement of Responsibilities, so that accountability for booking-arrangements oversight is clearly documented [#TGT:a696590f07b39032]. Separately, where individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, the firm should assess whether it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), recognising that firms have applied for SMF7 approval for individuals performing a range of functions [#TGT:a696590f07b39032].
source_text: In addition, the sections on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements [ Chapter 4 ] also apply to all PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that are headquartered in the UK or are part of a group based in the UK, and have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas. In this SS, these firms are denoted ‘UK trading banks’. These sections comprise paragraphs 4.1(d) , 4.20 , 4.23 , 4.25Y, 4.25AE , 5.14-5.16 and the Annex on Context and definitions. question: If an institution has trade exposures with a CCP, what steps must it follow to work out the exposure values first, and then turn those into risk-weighted exposure amounts?
gold_answer: An institution must follow a two-step process that links the exposure-value calculation to the risk-weighted outcome. First, it must calculate the exposure values of its trade exposures with a CCP using the applicable rules for exposure values set out in the relevant parts of the Chapter and, where applicable, the referenced part of Chapter 4 [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]. Second, once those exposure values have been determined, the institution must calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs by summing the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs and then multiplying that total by the risk weight determined under the relevant risk-weight determination approach [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]. Put simply, the target tells the institution how to compute the exposure values for trade exposures with a CCP, and the source tells the institution how to use those exposure values—by summing them and applying the appropriate risk weight—to arrive at the risk-weighted exposure amounts for those CCP trade exposures.
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: An institution shall calculate exposure values of its trade exposures with a CCP in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter and with Section 4 of Chapter 4, as applicable.

question: If Table A gives a default way to read EU-based references, what should you do in practice when the text mentions the Euro just as an example but treats other currencies (like US dollars) the same—do you need to change how you interpret it?
gold_answer: Use Table A first to identify the type of EU-based reference you are dealing with and apply the default approach it sets for interpreting that reference [#SRC:dd9730c74dae4fce]. Next, look at the currency wording: if the Euro is mentioned only as an example and the same treatment is applied to other currencies (such as US dollars), you should not change the interpretation you reached using the Table A default approach [#TGT:0f091b34fb7fe524]. In practical terms, the steps are: (1) anchor your reading in Table A’s default interpretive approach for the relevant EU-based reference; (2) confirm that the Euro is illustrative and that other currencies receive the same treatment; and (3) record that confirmation and continue with the same interpretation, without creating a separate rule or exception just because a different currency is used. This ensures the default interpretive method remains consistent while respecting the instruction that equivalent currency examples do not require interpretive changes.
source_text: Table A sets out the various different types of EU-based references, and a default approach to how these should be interpreted.
target_text: Where Euro is given as an example of a currency, and the same treatment is applied to other currencies (eg US dollars), no change in interpretation is required.

question: If a firm wants to restructure assets using a wholly owned special purpose vehicle (SPV), what does the PRA expect the firm to check about the original (unrestructured) asset over time, and when does the PRA think using this kind of restructuring is acceptable instead of options like pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows?
gold_answer: Using a wholly owned special purpose vehicle (SPV) to restructure assets may be acceptable, but only if the firm can show both that the underlying asset remains suitable for the MA portfolio liabilities over the relevant period and that the SPV approach is being used because other approaches are not viable. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] On the asset-suitability side, the PRA expects the firm first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to stay appropriate over time, in a way that matches the duration of the restructuring arrangement and reflects that operating conditions might change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] On the “when acceptable” side, the PRA highlights that restructuring adds complexity and consequential risks, so it expects firms to use these arrangements only where they have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, such as pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] The firm should also ensure the restructure is properly recognised within the firm and the group, including recognising any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation, and that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] In practice, the firm should connect the time-based review of the unrestructured asset to the justification for choosing an SPV only after alternatives have been ruled out. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: Restructuring of assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group, ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV), 22 may be acceptable, provided that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. It is important, however, that the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation. Given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring gives rise to, the PRA’s expectation is that these arrangements will only be used in cases where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, for example pairing/grouping, or partial recognition of cash flows.

question: If a firm keeps using a model even though back testing shows the results don’t match actual outcomes, what does that count as, and what should the firm’s approved process require for handling it (including escalation and any extra controls)?
gold_answer: If back testing indicates a model’s results are inconsistent with actual outcomes, that situation is treated as an “exception” under the definition provided. [#TGT:fff692c37fa26818] For a material model, the firm should have formally approved policies and procedures that spell out which exceptions it will allow and the escalation procedures it will follow to manage those exceptions. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] Because the issue arises from model performance, the firm should also have clear guidelines for setting a maximum tolerance for performance deviations from expectation. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] Once the firm’s defined triggers and thresholds are breached, the exception should be subject to appropriate risk controls and mitigants. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] The controls and mitigants described include using alternative models, applying heightened review and challenge, increasing monitoring after post-model adjustments, and recalibrating or redeveloping the existing methodology. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] This links the back-testing-based exception definition to the firm’s required escalation and control framework for material model exceptions. [#TGT:fff692c37fa26818] [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933]
source_text: a) For material models, firms should formulate the exceptions 23 they would allow for model use and model performance, and should implement formally approved policies and procedures setting out the escalation procedures to be followed and to manage these exceptions. (i) Exceptions for model use should be temporary, should be subject to post-model adjustments (PMAs), should be reported to and supported by stakeholders and senior management. (ii) For model performance exceptions, firms should have clear guidelines for determining a maximum tolerance on model performance exceptions (deviation from expectation), should be subject to appropriate risk controls (eg the use of alternative models, heightened review and challenge, and more frequent monitoring post-model adjustments) and mitigants (eg recalibrating or redevelopment of existing methodology) once defined triggers and thresholds are breached.
target_text: 23. Exceptions are defined here as using a model when not approved for usage by the appropriate oversight entity or not validated for use; a model is used outside its intended purpose; a model that displays persistent breach of performance metrics continues to be used; or back testing suggests the model results are inconsistent with actual outcomes.

question: When an issuer must determine the ‘relevant amount’ in relation to equity shares using profits after taxation from ordinary activities for the most recent financial year ending on or before the valuation date, what accounting basis must those profits be derived from, and what additional constraints apply regarding the accounts used and any capital structure changes?
gold_answer: In determining the ‘relevant amount’ for equity shares, the issuer must start from its profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the most recent financial year ending on or before the valuation date, but only to the extent those profits are attributable to the relevant equity shares and after taking account of the effect of any alterations in capital structure [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f]. Those profits must be taken from accounts that are reported in accordance with the applicable reporting requirement and are publicly available, because the definition ties the calculation to profits “reported in accounts” meeting that condition [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f]. In addition, the profits figure used for the relevant financial year must be derived from accounts drawn up under legislation implementing the Accounts Directives; if the accounts are not drawn up on that basis, the profits must instead be derived from accounts drawn up in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards or US generally accepted accounting practice [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3]. Read together, the issuer must ensure both the definitional inputs (attribution to equity shares, capital-structure adjustments, and public availability) and the mandated accounting framework for the source accounts are satisfied [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3].
source_text: For the purposes of 11.6 , the ‘relevant amount’ in relation to equity shares is the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the most recent financial year ending on or before the valuation date which is reported in accounts in accordance with 11.8 which are publicly available, in so far as attributable to those equity shares , taking account of the effect of any alterations in capital structure.
target_text: For the purposes of 11.7 , the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the relevant financial year must be derived from accounts drawn up in accordance with legislation implementing the Accounts Directives or, if accounts are not so drawn up, from accounts drawn up in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards or US generally accepted accounting practice.

question: If a firm is a small CRR firm (or a small third country CRR firm), can it say it benefits from a derogation “on the basis of” 12.2 or 15A, and if it is reporting a derogation, what details does it have to give about the staff and pay affected?
gold_answer: A firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm should not state that it benefits from a derogation “on the basis of” 12.2 or 15A, because those provisions are described as not applying to that type of firm. [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03] Separately, when the institution is required to indicate that it benefits from a derogation for the relevant reporting purpose, it must provide specific information about the derogation’s use and impact, not just a rule reference. [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6] The required details include: which remuneration principles the derogation(s) are applied to; the number of staff members who benefit from the derogation(s); and the total remuneration of those staff, split into fixed remuneration and variable remuneration. [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6] This means the firm must align any “basis” it cites with the rules that actually apply to it, while still giving the full staff-and-remuneration breakdown for any derogation it reports. [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03] [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6]
source_text: For the purposes of point (k) of the first subparagraph of this paragraph, institutions that benefit from such a derogation shall indicate whether they benefit from that derogation on the basis of the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at 5.3 , and/or 12.2 (second subparagraph), and 15.A1 (3) . They shall also indicate for which of the remuneration principles they apply the derogation(s), the number of staff members that benefit from the derogation(s) and their total remuneration , split into fixed and variable remuneration .
target_text: 12.2 , 15.15 to 15.19 , 15.20 (2) and (3A), 15.20A to 15.23 and 15A do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm .

question: Where a firm has permission to use a partial or full internal model and is using an internal model for reporting to the PRA, what must it submit each quarter to evidence minor and major model changes, and what content must that quarterly submission cover?
gold_answer: A firm that has permission to use a partial or full internal model and is using an internal model must provide the PRA with a quarterly submission that both (i) delivers a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes and (ii) is made using the PRA’s prescribed quarterly reporting template for model changes. Specifically, the firm is required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA, reflecting the reporting expectation tied to the PRA Rulebook reporting framework and the EIOPA Guidelines on internal models [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd]. In addition, the firm must submit the PRA quarterly template QMC.01, which must specify information on model changes and include supporting qualitative information, prepared in line with the applicable template instructions referenced for QMC.01 [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2]. Read together, the obligation is not satisfied by an informal narrative alone: the quarterly summary of changes must be delivered through the required QMC.01 submission and must include both the change information and the supporting qualitative explanation required by the template instructions, ensuring the PRA receives consistent, structured reporting on both minor and major model changes each quarter.
source_text: In accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models, firms with permission to use a partial or full internal model are required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: For purposes of preparing the Merger Document(s), how should the firm characterise and handle the proxy voting forms referenced alongside a covering letter—specifically, what instrument is being referred to and what function must it serve in relation to a meeting of a society?
gold_answer: The proxy voting forms referenced as part of the “other documents” that may accompany the Merger Document(s), including a covering letter, should be treated as the instrument by which a member authorises another person to act for them at a society meeting. In particular, the relevant form is an instrument appointing a proxy to attend a meeting of a society and to vote on the member’s behalf, so its core function is representation and voting at that meeting rather than merely providing information. This means that, when assembling the Merger Document(s) package, the proxy voting forms should be included and described consistently with their role as a proxy appointment instrument, and the covering letter can be used as an accompanying document within the same set of materials. The linkage is that the source contemplates inclusion of proxy voting forms as part of the merger documentation bundle [#SRC:81e3009351497661], while the target defines what those proxy voting forms are in substance—an instrument appointing a proxy for attendance and voting at a society meeting [#TGT:075179a0e3b09cfe].
source_text: (c) any other documents, such as a covering letter for the Merger Document(s) and proxy voting forms; 31
target_text: 31. An instrument appointing a proxy to attend a meeting of a society and vote on the member’s behalf.

question: If the parties disagree about the value of the technical provisions being transferred, which value should be used to check whether the PRA’s run-off scheme thresholds are met, and what does the PRA say about doing an s166 assessment before naming the independent expert?
gold_answer: When the parties have different valuations for the technical provisions being transferred, the value used to test whether a threshold is met is the higher valuation. [#TGT:6859654d7bfc4b42] Using that higher figure, the scheme should then be assessed against the PRA’s stated conditions for when it generally intends to commission an s166 assessment: the scheme must involve a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, the gross technical provisions must be more than £100 million, and the scheme must increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] If those conditions are met (as determined using the higher valuation where there is disagreement), the PRA indicates it intends in most cases to use its powers under s166 of FSMA to assess whether the transferee is operationally ready to accept the scheme. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] The PRA also states the sequencing for that work: the assessment would be commissioned before the independent expert is nominated. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] An exception is also described: the PRA may decide it can satisfy itself by other means, such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8]
source_text: Where a scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, with gross technical provisions of more than £100 million, 10 and where the scheme will increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%, the PRA intends to exercise its powers under s166 of FSMA in order to assess the operational readiness of the transferee to accept the scheme in most cases, except where it is able to satisfy itself by other means such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. This assessment would be commissioned prior to the nomination of the independent expert.
target_text: 10. If the parties have differing valuations of the technical provisions being transferred, the higher valuation will be used in determining whether the threshold is triggered.

question: Within the PRA Rulebook Conditions Governing Business material that frames the General Governance Requirements and related chapters, which entities are required to implement governance arrangements, and what is the core governance outcome they must achieve for the management of their business?
gold_answer: The PRA Rulebook Conditions Governing Business material identifies the governance-focused content area by pointing to the General Governance Requirements and related chapters on risk management and outsourcing, establishing the context in which governance expectations are addressed [#SRC:1b62e98bf7fca2b2]. Within that context, the operative obligation applies to “a firm,” which is the actor expressly named as subject to the requirement [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. The firm must implement and maintain an effective system of governance, and that system must be designed to deliver a specific management outcome: it must support sound and prudent management of the firm’s business [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. Read together, the source frames the applicability as part of the Conditions Governing Business governance requirements (and adjacent governance-relevant topics such as risk management and outsourcing), while the target supplies the concrete duty and standard the firm must meet—effectiveness of the governance system and the soundness and prudence of business management [#SRC:1b62e98bf7fca2b2] [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6].
source_text: PRA Rulebook Conditions Governing Business ; 16 Rules 2.2 to 2.6 – General Governance Requirements ; 17 Chapter 3 – Risk Management ; Chapter 7 - Outsourcing ; 18
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place an effective system of governance which provides for sound and prudent management of its business.

question: When applying to the PRA for approval of a Merger Notification Statement before sending it to members within the specified time limit, what written application content and board-level declaration is expected, and how should the statement address any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society?
gold_answer: The applicant should treat the approval request as a written submission to the PRA that both supports timely member communication and demonstrates completeness and transparency, while ensuring the Merger Notification Statement contains the required compensation particulars. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Specifically, the Merger Notification Statement must be approved by the PRA before it is issued to members and it must be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] In making the application, it must be in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and contains all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should know. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also state whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm the accuracy of the information about them. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] In addition, the Merger Notification Statement itself must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application should also be accompanied by documents, and (for Merger Notification Statements) the final draft should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed for that purpose, adapted to the case and the less extensive information required in the statement. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application for a Schedule 16 Statement is likewise described as being accompanied by documents. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50]
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.

question: If the PRA buffer is being set for a new bank using six months of forward operating expenses, can the PRA switch to setting it using a stress test instead, and does the bank need to be profitable first?
gold_answer: The source describes the PRA buffer being set on a new bank basis using a forward-looking measure of operating expenses over six months, which indicates the expected approach for a bank in its early phase [#SRC:e5a499171debe53f]. The target adds that, by that point, the PRA buffer could be set on a stress test basis, but only if the bank has reached profitability [#TGT:cc064b0f7310d0e8]. Putting both together, the PRA can move away from the new‑bank, six‑months‑forward operating‑expenses basis and instead set the PRA buffer on a stress test basis at that stage, but the permission to do so is tied to a specific condition: the bank must have reached profitability. If the bank has not reached profitability, the passages do not indicate that the stress‑test basis is available at that point, so the new bank basis (six months forward operating expenses) remains the applicable way the PRA buffer is set. This links the method change directly to the bank’s profitability status.
source_text: PRA buffer set on new bank basis (6 months forward operating expenses) 47
target_text: 47. Although the PRA buffer could be set on a stress test basis by this point if the bank has reached profitability (see paragraph 4.8).

question: If a rule applied to managing agents mentions “SCR”, what does it mean in this context, and what does a managing agent have to calculate for each syndicate it manages?
gold_answer: In this context, when a rule is applied to managing agents and it uses the term “SCR”, that term must be read as referring to the notional syndicate SCR that managing agents calculate, rather than being left as an undefined or generic SCR reference [#SRC:44175f318dae3378]. That interpretation is not just definitional; it connects directly to the managing agent’s required action. Specifically, a managing agent must calculate a notional SCR for each syndicate which it manages, and that per-syndicate calculation is the same notional syndicate SCR that the applied rules are pointing to when they say “SCR” [#TGT:aabb18c60cd5c8ad]. So, whenever the managing agent is checking compliance with those applied provisions, it should treat “SCR” as a shorthand for the notional syndicate SCR and ensure the calculation is actually performed for every syndicate under its management [#SRC:44175f318dae3378]. The obligation is therefore both interpretive (how to read “SCR”) and practical (perform the notional SCR calculation for each managed syndicate) [#TGT:aabb18c60cd5c8ad].
source_text: (1) 3.1 (2)(b), 3.8 (2)(c) and 6.1 (1)(i), as applied to managing agents , the reference to “ SCR ” is to be interpreted as a reference to the notional syndicate SCR calculated by managing agents as required by Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 8.2 .
target_text: A managing agent must calculate a notional SCR for each syndicate which it manages.

question: For the relevant subsidiaries, what does the procedure require you to do with the Bank’s views on whether the resolution group can achieve outcomes comparable to the Bank of England’s resolvability approach, and what date is given for the update you should be looking at?
gold_answer: For the relevant subsidiaries, the procedure requires you to take into account the Bank’s views on a defined issue: whether the resolution group’s capabilities would deliver resolvability outcomes that are broadly comparable to those set out in the Statement of Policy called “The Bank of England’s Approach to Assessing Resolvability” [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a]. The related reference material that points you to an update of that approach is tied to a specific date, which is the concrete timing detail you should use when identifying the correct update: “July 2019” [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e]. Using both passages together, you should (1) frame your assessment around the Bank’s views on comparability between the resolution group’s capabilities and the SoP’s resolvability outcomes, and (2) ensure you are consulting the update identified as July 2019 when you look up the Bank of England’s updated approach. This ensures your work reflects the required Bank-view-informed comparison and is anchored to the dated update reference provided, rather than an undated or unspecified version of the approach [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a] [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e].
source_text: (i) for the relevant subsidiaries, taking into account the Bank’s views as to whether the capabilities of the resolution group would deliver resolvability outcomes that are broadly comparable to those set out in the Statement of Policy (SoP) ‘The Bank of England’s Approach to Assessing Resolvability’; 19
target_text: 19. July 2019: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/paper/2020/updates-to-the-boes-approach-to-assessing-resolvability .

question: If the rules don’t say how to value a certain type of asset, what value should be used, and how should that value be changed if the firm is treated as having bought or sold that asset type because of an option when working out its exposure using the 19 to 23 adjustments?
gold_answer: If there is no specific valuation provision for a particular description of assets, the firm must still ascribe a value, using the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] That ascribed value is the basis for calculating exposure, because the firm’s exposure to assets of each description is determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] When the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets of a given description pursuant to an option, the value ascribed for assets of that description (under 18 to 19) must be increased or decreased by the value of the assets the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] So, even where the initial valuation is based on a reasonable immediate transfer price (because the rules are silent for that asset type), the firm must still apply the option-driven increase or decrease to the ascribed value for that asset description as part of the overall adjustment process used to determine exposure under 19 to 23. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: If a firm is working out MCR(l,gi) as the linear part for long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations linked to general insurance business, what method must it follow, and what data must it leave out when choosing technical provisions or premiums written?
gold_answer: MCR(l,gi) is defined as the linear formula component for the firm’s long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations that relate to general insurance business [#SRC:bcc921ae0bcf10dd]. Because it is a linear component, the firm must calculate MCR(l,gi) using the same approach that applies to the relevant linear MCR measures: the rule requires that MCR(gi,gi) and MCR(l,gi) be calculated in the same way as MCR(linear,gi) and MCR(linear,l) respectively [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478]. However, even when the firm follows that same calculation method, it cannot use just any technical provisions or premiums written as inputs. The technical provisions or premiums written used in the calculation must be restricted so they only relate to the firm’s general insurance and reinsurance obligations [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478]. So, in practice, the firm should treat MCR(l,gi) as the specific linear component for long-term obligations connected to general insurance business, apply the required linear calculation approach, and exclude any technical provisions or premiums written that do not relate to general insurance and reinsurance obligations [#SRC:bcc921ae0bcf10dd] [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478].
source_text: (2) MCR(l,gi) denotes the linear formula component for long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations relating to general insurance business calculated in accordance with 4A.5 .
target_text: MCR (gi,gi) and MCR (l,gi) must be calculated in the same way as MCR (linear,gi) and MCR (linear,l) referred to in Minimum Capital Requirement 3B and 3C respectively, but the technical provisions or premiums written used in the calculation must only relate to the firm’s general insurance and reinsurance obligations .

question: If an asset type isn’t covered by the valuation rules, how do you pick its value, and after you adjust that value to get the firm’s exposure, do you also need to add anything for the firm’s dependants?
gold_answer: You must first assign a value to the assets and then calculate the firm’s exposure by adjusting that value, and after that you must add any relevant exposure of the firm’s dependants for the same asset description. [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] Where the rules in this Part do not provide a valuation method for a particular asset description, the value used must be the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] The firm’s exposure to assets of each description is determined by taking the asset value and applying the required adjustments under the specified provisions (19 to 23). [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] After the exposure amount has been determined in accordance with 18 to 22, that exposure must be increased by an amount representing any exposure of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description, unless 23.2 or 23.3 applies. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] Practically, this means the dependant-related amount is not part of the initial valuation step; it is an additional increase applied to the exposure figure that results from the valuation-and-adjustment process, and it is tied to the same asset description you are measuring for the firm. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6]
source_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .
target_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.

question: When an institution is required to set up hedging sets for a netting set and allocate transactions to them, how must it treat the index that denotes all interest risk rate hedging sets established for that netting set, and how does that index relate to the institution’s obligation to establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category?
gold_answer: Institutions must operationalise their obligation to establish hedging sets and allocate transactions by ensuring that, for each netting set, the interest risk rate hedging sets they establish are captured under the defined index “j”, which denotes all such interest risk rate hedging sets established for that netting set [#SRC:73f861950b2825dc]. In practice, this means that when Institutions establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category of a netting set and assign each transaction to those hedging sets [#TGT:618dbcc272a2044a], they should treat “j” as the complete identifier set for the interest risk rate hedging sets within that netting set, so that transaction assignment can be performed against a clearly delimited universe of interest risk rate hedging sets. The definition of “j” is netting-set specific and is tied to hedging sets “established in accordance with” the referenced establishment conditions, so Institutions should ensure that the hedging sets they create for interest risk rate are the ones encompassed by that index and that transaction allocation is made to those established sets rather than to any ad hoc or undefined groupings. This aligns the definitional scope of the index with the required establishment-and-assignment process.
