question: If the Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary is supposed to go out with the meeting notice, what happens if someone who should get it doesn’t receive it? When is that treated as an “accidental omission,” and when is it not (for example, if there’s a computer mailing-list problem or management decides not to send to a group)?
gold_answer: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the meeting notice to every person who is entitled to receive it, so a missing delivery is assessed in the same overall context as notice delivery. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] For meeting validity, the scrutineers’ report may properly take into account that an accidental failure to give notice, or a person’s non-receipt of the notice, does not automatically invalidate what the meeting does. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] But the society should not treat every mistake as “accidental.” [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] The “accidental omission” idea does not include systemic failures to send notices, such as not sending to new shareholders or borrowers, or leaving out a whole group/class because a computer programme fault caused them to be missing from the mailing list. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] Also, authority indicates that “accidental” and “non-receipt” do not cover all “error,” including a management mistake where management wrongly decides not to send notices to particular persons or groups. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] So, isolated accidental lapses may be treated differently from systemic or management-driven exclusions when evaluating notice compliance and reporting. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0]
source_text: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the notice to every person entitled to receive it (paragraphs 2 and 4 of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act). Accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to any person entitled to receive it does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting. However, ‘accidental omission’ does not include a systemic failure to send notices (eg omitting to send notices to new shareholders or borrowers, or omission of a group or class of members from the mailing list arising from a fault in a computer programme), nor all cases of error by management – see also paragraph 4.153 .
target_text: In relation to the notice of the meeting, the scrutineers’ report may properly have regard to the provision of paragraph 22(3) of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act that ‘accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to, or non-receipt of notice of a meeting by, any person entitled to receive notice of the meeting does not invalidate the proceedings at that meeting’. It should be noted, however, that there is authority to the effect that ‘accidental’ and ‘non-receipt’ would not cover all cases of ‘error’ on the part of the society, for example an erroneous decision of management not to send notices to particular persons or groups of persons.

question: When checking the PRA’s under-£130 million limit for FSCS covered instant access deposits at branches, what does “instant access account” mean, and which balances should be counted?
gold_answer: When you check the PRA expectation for branches, you should count only the retail and small company instant access account balances that are covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme, and the total of those counted balances is expected to stay under £130 million. [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] An “instant access account” is one where customers can take money out unconditionally, so they can withdraw without having to give notice and without having to pay penalties. [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3] Put together, this means you identify retail and small company accounts that meet the unconditional-withdrawal test (no notice and no penalties) and then include their FSCS-covered balances in the branch total for the £130 million expectation. [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] The withdrawal-condition definition is what determines whether an account is in scope for the “instant access” part of the PRA expectation, so it directly affects which balances you add up against the cap. [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3]
source_text: (a) FSCS covered instant access deposits: the PRA expects branches to have under £130 million of retail and small company 55 instant access 56 account balances covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS);
target_text: 56. An instant access account means accounts from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, without providing notice or paying penalties.

question: While waiting for a change in control to happen after a section 178 notice is sent, what should a UK domestic firm keep checking about the controller or proposed controller, and when does it have to tell the PRA if it thinks the notice information might be wrong or has materially changed?
gold_answer: In that interim period, the UK domestic firm has two linked responsibilities: keep itself up to date on the relevant person’s situation and escalate problems to the PRA without delay when certain warning signs appear. During the period referred to in 3.6, the firm must take reasonable steps to stay informed about the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller that the notification was about. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] Separately, in the period between submitting a section 178 notice and the occurrence of the change in control, the firm must notify the PRA immediately if it becomes aware, or has information that reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have given the PRA information that was or may have false, misleading, incomplete, or inaccurate, or that the information has or may have changed in a material particular. [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e] The practical linkage is that the ongoing “reasonable steps” monitoring is what positions the firm to detect the kinds of potential inaccuracies or material changes that trigger the immediate notification duty during that same pre-change window. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]
source_text: During the period referred to in 3.6 , a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or the proposed controller to which the notification related.
target_text: (1) A UK domestic firm must notify the PRA immediately if, in the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control , the firm becomes aware, or has information which reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information which was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular.

question: In meeting the obligation to project TWD scenario impacts through the wind-down period, how should TWD firms align their methodologies, models, and frameworks with the requirement to include all necessary risk and trade data, particularly where projections depend on sensitivity analysis and alternative segmentation of trading portfolios?
gold_answer: TWD firms should align their methodologies, models, and frameworks with the scope and granularity of the inputs required to run them, so that projections remain supportable from the reference date through the wind-down period. The obligation to forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity presupposes that the firm’s analytical toolkit can generate projections over the relevant horizon [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e]. That toolkit must be underpinned by a dataset that includes all risk and trade data necessary to calculate financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, rather than a partial or high-level subset [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. The same data should also support segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways, enabling the firm to reflect different portfolio groupings that may be used to execute wind-down actions (including alternative packaging of trades for novation) [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. Together, these requirements mean the firm’s models and frameworks should be designed to consume and reconcile portfolio segmentations and sensitivities so that capital and liquidity forecasts remain coherent under different wind-down execution paths.
source_text: This should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis in paragraphs 4.25 - 4.51 , including information to support segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways (for example, alternative packaging of trades for novation).

question: If Institutions are working out replacement cost for a single netting set under a margin agreement (and it is not in the separate treatment mentioned), what MF value must they use for transactions that sit in the cross-referred netting sets, and where does that MF fit into what they must calculate?
gold_answer: Institutions have to calculate the replacement cost for each single netting set that is subject to a margin agreement, except for those netting sets that fall under the separate treatment mentioned, and they must do this using the required formula-based method for replacement cost [#TGT:19512cdca8e04e88]. For the part of that calculation that relates to transactions included in the specific netting sets that are cross-referred to in the relevant provision, Institutions must set the margin factor (MF) to 0.42 [#SRC:465c803c2a417476]. In practice, this means the replacement cost calculation obligation tells Institutions what they must compute (replacement cost for the qualifying single netting set using the formula), while the MF requirement tells them the exact parameter value they must plug in when the transactions being captured are those included in the cross-referred netting sets. The two requirements operate together: the formula-based replacement cost calculation is mandatory, and MF = 0.42 is mandatory for that defined subset of transactions.

question: When a firm is assessing whether it has sufficient credible recovery options to restore capital and liquidity in or after a stress, how should it incorporate both (i) the likely actions of peers (including potential constraints on issuing equity in a market-wide stress) and (ii) scenario testing to demonstrate the recovery plan works across different stresses and that plan elements interact appropriately?
gold_answer: A firm should assess recovery options in a way that both (1) evidences it can restore capital and liquidity to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress and (2) uses scenario testing to show the recovery plan remains usable across different stress types and that its components work together. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] In practice, the firm should treat peer behaviour and market-wide conditions as key assumptions when judging the real capacity of its options, and then validate those assumptions through scenario testing that exercises the plan end-to-end. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] Operationally, this means the firm should: (i) identify credible options intended to restore capital and liquidity positions; (ii) assess each option’s capacity under stress while explicitly considering likely peer actions; and (iii) reflect market-wide stress constraints, such as reduced ability to issue equity, when evaluating feasibility. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] The firm should then run scenario testing across a range of different types of stress to demonstrate the recovery plan is suitable for use, and to test how indicators, governance, and options would interact under those stresses (including the peer-action and equity-issuance constraints embedded in the option capacity assessment). [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure they have sufficient credible options to restore their capital and liquidity positions to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress. In assessing the capacity of these options, firms should take into account the likely actions of peers in a stress. For example, firms should assess whether their ability to issue equity will be diminished in a market wide stress. See also ‘ (iv) Scenario testing ’ below.
target_text: Scenario testing is important for demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress, and testing how different elements of the plan (such as indicators, governance and options) would interact in these stresses.

question: When the PRA’s supervisory action results in the issue of a Decision Notice or a Final Notice, what must the PRA publish about the matters concerned, and how does the PRA’s ordinary practice of publishing action in relation to supervisory decisions align with its discretion over the manner of publication?
gold_answer: Where the PRA’s supervisory action leads to the issue of a Decision Notice or a Final Notice, the PRA must publish information about the matters to which those notices relate, and it must do so in such manner as it considers appropriate [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02]. In parallel, the PRA’s stated approach is that it will consider the circumstances of each case but will ordinarily publish action in relation to supervisory decisions when that action has led to the issue of a Decision Notice, and likewise where it has led to the issue of a Final Notice [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6]. Read together, the TARGET establishes a publication requirement tied to the matters covered by specified notices, while the SOURCE explains the PRA’s usual practice of publicising the fact of action taken in relation to supervisory decisions in the Decision Notice and Final Notice outcomes. The PRA’s discretion is not whether to publish in these notice scenarios, but how it publishes the required information, with the SOURCE indicating that the PRA may vary its approach depending on the circumstances of each case while still ordinarily publishing in these outcomes [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02] [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6].
source_text: The PRA will consider the circumstances of each case, but, subject to paragraph 7 above, will ordinarily publish action in relation to supervisory decisions when this has led to the issue of a Decision Notice, as well as where it has led to the issue of a Final Notice.
target_text: Section 391 of the Act also requires the PRA to publish – in such manner as it considers appropriate – information about the matters to which a Supervisory Notice, 22 a Decision Notice, and a Final Notice relate.

question: While a section 178 notice is pending (after it is submitted but before the change in control happens), what does a UK domestic firm have to do to keep up to date on the controller or proposed controller, and what must it do right away if it learns or has reasonable indications that the notice submitter’s information to the PRA may be wrong or has materially changed?
gold_answer: In the period after a section 178 notice is submitted and before the change in control occurs, a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller that the notification relates to [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979]. This means the firm should not simply rely on what was initially submitted; it must stay alert to relevant developments in those circumstances during the pending period. If, in that same period, the firm becomes aware, or has information that reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information that was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular, the firm must notify the PRA immediately [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]. The two requirements work together: the ongoing reasonable-steps duty helps the firm detect issues, and the immediate notification duty sets the required response once such an issue is identified.
source_text: During the period referred to in 3.6 , a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or the proposed controller to which the notification related.
target_text: (1) A UK domestic firm must notify the PRA immediately if, in the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control , the firm becomes aware, or has information which reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information which was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular.

question: If a managing agents is using an internal model to work out the notional syndicate SCR, what does “internal model” mean in that situation, and what must a firm with internal model permission make sure its risk-management function does as a result?
gold_answer: In the managing agents context, when the applied rules use the phrase “internal model,” it is not a special or limited term: it must be understood as referring to any internal model that a managing agents uses to calculate the notional syndicate SCR [#SRC:fcea9d1469b85659]. Separately, if a firm has received internal model permission, it must take a concrete governance step: it must ensure that its risk-management function covers additional tasks (i.e., tasks that are specifically extra because the firm has that permission) [#TGT:f3398a0e786dcdd5]. Putting these together, the interpretation tells you which models fall within scope for the managing agents’ notional syndicate SCR calculation, and the permission-based requirement tells you what the firm must do organisationally—make sure the risk-management function’s remit expands to cover the additional tasks associated with internal model permission. The combined effect is that the firm should not treat only one particular model as relevant; instead, the risk-management function’s expanded coverage must be set up with the understanding that “internal model” includes any model used for that notional syndicate SCR purpose.

question: What is the PRA trying to achieve by clearly explaining what it expects from firms, and how does that connect to the fact that the statement was consulted on through PRA Consultation Paper 27/15 about the prudential regime for non-Solvency II insurance firms?
gold_answer: The PRA says the statement is meant to make its expectations of firms clear and consistent for the particular areas it covers, and that doing so is intended to help the PRA meet its statutory objectives [#SRC:36ada05817560484]. Those objectives include ensuring the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates and contributing to securing an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders [#SRC:36ada05817560484]. The statement is also described as having been consulted on in CP27/15, and the related consultation is identified as “PRA Consultation Paper 27/15” on “The prudential regime for non-Solvency II insurance firms and consequential amendments,” dated August 2015, with a published link [#TGT:f5627a456d43aae2]. Putting both passages together, the PRA is not only explaining what it expects and why (to support safety and soundness and policyholder protection), but also showing that these expectations were developed through a formal consultation process tied to CP27/15, which provides the consultation context for the statement’s approach [#SRC:36ada05817560484] [#TGT:f5627a456d43aae2].
source_text: This statement was consulted on in CP27/15 1 and expands on the PRA’s general approach 2 . By clearly and consistently explaining its expectations of firms in relation to the particular areas addressed, the PRA seeks to advance its statutory objectives of ensuring the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates, and contributing to securing an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders. The PRA has considered matters to which it is required to have regard, and it considers that this statement is compatible with the Regulatory Principles and relevant provisions of the Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006.
target_text: 1. PRA Consultation Paper 27/15 The prudential regime for non-Solvency II insurance firms and consequential amendments, August 2015; http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/pra/Pages/publications/cp/2015/cp2715.aspx
